articles.headline: U.S. General Says Raiding Syria Is Key to Halting ISIS
articles.snippet: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey was circumspect in describing the sort of broad effort that would be required to roll back ISIS in Syria and Iraq.
articles.abstract: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey was circumspect in describing the sort of broad effort that would be required to roll back ISIS in Syria and Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria cannot be defeated unless the United States or its partners take on the Sunni militants in Syria, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Regulators Struggle With Conflicts in Credit Ratings and Audits
articles.snippet: Two industries with obvious conflicts of interest are having trouble adjusting to government regulation, and regulators are having trouble deciding what to do about them.
articles.abstract: Two industries with obvious conflicts of interest are having trouble adjusting to government regulation, and regulators are having trouble deciding what to do about them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few businesses have more obvious conflicts of interest than those that involve the issuing of “objective” and “independent” reports and opinions about companies that pay for those reports and opinions.

articles.headline: Natural Gas Production Falls Short in China
articles.snippet: The nation, facing severe pollution from coal and a rising dependence on energy imports, has had limited success in extracting natural gas from coal and shale.
articles.abstract: The nation, facing severe pollution from coal and a rising dependence on energy imports, has had limited success in extracting natural gas from coal and shale.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHOUYANG, China — Jin Peisheng, a drilling rig foreman, knows the challenges of trying to extract natural gas from a coal seam under the cornfields here in north-central China.

articles.headline: Marketers Are Sizing Up the Millennials
articles.snippet: Marketers, manufacturers and retailers are recognizing the group’s potential as the consumers who will drive the economy in the decades ahead.
articles.abstract: Marketers, manufacturers and retailers are recognizing the group’s potential as the consumers who will drive the economy in the decades ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millennials have been called a lot of names. Narcissistic, lazy, indecisive. They have been labeled the boomerang generation for the many unable or unwilling to leave their parents’ home, or even more negatively, the Peter Pan generation because they supposedly won’t grow up.

articles.headline: Short-Lived Science Line From Lego for Girls
articles.snippet: The Danish toymaker debuted Research Institute, its first line aimed at girls to feature women in a professional setting rather than at play or partying.
articles.abstract: The Danish toymaker debuted Research Institute, its first line aimed at girls to feature women in a professional setting rather than at play or partying.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lego is demonstrating this summer that role models in science and technology for girls are still fairly scarce in toy land, just as in the real world.

articles.headline: A Terrorist Horror, Then Golf: Incongruity Fuels Obama Critics
articles.snippet: As the president returned to his vacation, a firestorm of criticism from Republicans and Democrats erupted over what many saw as a callous indifference to the slaughter of James Foley.
articles.abstract: As the president returned to his vacation, a firestorm of criticism from Republicans and Democrats erupted over what many saw as a callous indifference to the slaughter of James Foley.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He had just hung up the telephone with the devastated parents before heading in front of the cameras. Unusually emotional, President Obama declared himself “heartbroken” by the brutal murder of an American journalist, James Foley, and vowed to “be relentless” against Islamic radicals threatening to kill another American.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Russians Open Fire in Ukraine, NATO Reports
articles.snippet: NATO officials said that the Russian military had moved artillery units inside Ukrainian territory in recent days and was using them to fire at Ukrainian forces.
articles.abstract: NATO officials said that the Russian military had moved artillery units inside Ukrainian territory in recent days and was using them to fire at Ukrainian forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Russia on Friday escalated tensions with Ukraine to the highest level since its stealthy invasion of Crimea in the spring, sending more than 200 trucks from a long-stalled aid convoy into rebel-held eastern Ukraine over the objections of Kiev and, NATO said, conducting military operations on Ukrainian territory.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Fed Chief Sees Not Enough Data to Raise Rates
articles.snippet: At her first keynote speech for the Federal Reserve’s annual conference, Janet Yellen says she wants to see more evidence of a labor market recovery.
articles.abstract: At her first keynote speech for the Federal Reserve’s annual conference, Janet Yellen says she wants to see more evidence of a labor market recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Friday that the economy was improving but that the Fed was awaiting more evidence about the health of labor markets before deciding when to start raising interest rates.
